questions.text: In SAFE strategy for Trachoma, ‘surgery’ stands for correction of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichiasis

 

Option B: Trichiasis refers to the inward curling of eyelash. Surgery is aimed at relieving trichiasis and entropion.

 

SAFE strategy was an intervention done to combat trachoma:

 

  • Surgery to correct lid and lash deformity & prevent blindness
  • Antibiotics for acute infections & community control
  • Facial hygiene
  • Environmental change- improved sanitation

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ptosis, or drooping of the eyelid, is not the target of surgery in the SAFE strategy for Trachoma. Ptosis may be caused by a variety of conditions, but it is not a direct consequence of Trachoma.

 

Option C. Squint, or strabismus, is a condition where the eyes do not properly align with each other when looking at an object. It is not specifically addressed in the SAFE strategy for Trachoma.

 

Option D. A Hordeolum, commonly known as a stye, is an acute infection of the oil glands of the eyelid. This is not a condition treated by the surgery component of the SAFE strategy for Trachoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the SAFE strategy for Trachoma, "Surgery" refers to the surgical correction of Trichiasis, a condition where eyelashes turn inward and rub against the cornea, potentially leading to corneal scarring and blindness. This intervention is crucial to prevent the progression of visual impairment in Trachoma patients.

 

Ref: Pg 72/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: A 25-year-old individual presents to the clinic with sudden-onset severe eye redness, copious purulent discharge, and marked eyelid swelling. The patient reports recent unprotected high risk sexual contact. What is the most likely causative organism of this hyperacute conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gonococcus

 

Option A: The presentation of sudden-onset severe eye redness, copious purulent discharge, and marked eyelid swelling, especially in the context of recent high-risk sexual contact, strongly suggests hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a Gonococcus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas Aeruginosa, a less common cause of conjunctivitis, is typically associated with contact lens wearers. While it can cause a severe and sight-threatening infection, it is not typically associated with the sexual transmission or the severe purulent discharge seen in gonococcal conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Chlamydia Trachomatis can cause inclusion conjunctivitis, particularly in sexually active young adults. However, its presentation is usually more subacute or chronic, and not as hyperacute or severely purulent as gonococcal conjunctivitis.

 

 

Option D. Adenovirus is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis, often leading to watery discharge, irritation, and conjunctival redness. However, adenoviral infections do not typically cause the severe purulent discharge or the marked eyelid swelling seen in gonococcal conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young adult presenting with sudden-onset severe eye redness, copious purulent discharge, and marked eyelid swelling, especially with a history of high-risk sexual behavior, gonococcal conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most likely diagnosis. Prompt identification and treatment are crucial to prevent complications.

 

Ref: Pg 64/CONJUNCTIVA/Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/6th Edition

questions.text: FISTO classification is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trachoma

 

Option C: FISTO classification is used for staging trachoma.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alkali Injury: The classification for ocular chemical burns, like alkali injuries, is typically the Roper-Hall or Dua classification. These systems assess the extent of limbal ischemia and corneal damage to predict prognosis.

 

 

Roper Hall classification of alkali injuries.

 

Option B. Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is often graded based on the severity and type of conjunctival changes, such as papillary hypertrophy and corneal involvement. However, the FISTO classification is not used for VKC.

 

Option D. Ocular herpes simplex is typically diagnosed based on clinical features and confirmed by laboratory tests. Classification systems for herpes simplex keratitis focus on the location and type of the lesions (e.g., dendritic ulcers, stromal keratitis), rather than using the FISTO classification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The FISTO classification is specifically used for grading Trachoma, assessing the presence and severity of Follicles, Inflammation, Scarring, Trichiasis, and Opacity to guide treatment and prognostic evaluation.

 

Ref:

 

  1. Pg 70/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition
  2.  Soleimani, Mohammad & Naderan, Morteza. (2020). Management Strategies of Ocular Chemical Burns: Current Perspectives. Clinical Ophthalmology (Auckland, N.Z.). 14. 2687-2699. 10.2147/OPTH.S235873.

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active female presents to the emergency department with redness, purulent discharge, and marked eyelid swelling in the left eye. On further evaluation, the diagnosis of gonococcal conjunctivitis is confirmed. Which of the following complications is the patient at the highest risk for if left untreated?
questions.solution:
Ans: A) Corneal Ulceration:

 

Option A: Corneal Ulceration: Untreated gonococcal conjunctivitis can lead to severe corneal involvement, including corneal ulceration. This complication results from the direct invasion of Neisseria gonorrhoeae into the cornea and can cause significant vision impairment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cataract Formation: While cataract formation is a potential complication of ocular infections, it is not the primary concern in gonococcal conjunctivitis. Corneal involvement and subsequent complications are more common in this condition.

 

Option C. Retinal Detachment: Retinal detachment is not typically associated with gonococcal conjunctivitis. It occurs due to the separation of the retina from the underlying tissue and is not a common sequela of this type of conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Optic Neuritis: Optic neuritis refers to inflammation of the optic nerve and can lead to vision impairment. It is not a direct complication of gonococcal conjunctivitis. Complications in gonococcal conjunctivitis usually involve the anterior segment of the eye, such as the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient with gonococcal conjunctivitis is at the highest risk for the complication of Corneal ulceration. This complication can result in significant vision loss and highlights the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of gonococcal conjunctivitis to prevent severe ocular damage.

 

Ref: Pg 64/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

choices.text: A, B, Ba, C

questions.text: A 7-day-old neonate develops conjunctivitis, diagnosed as neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia. Which of the following serotype is responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) D to K

 

Option B: These serotypes are associated with urogenital infections and ocular infections such as inclusion conjunctivitis. Neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis, acquired during passage through the birth canal from an infected mother, is commonly caused by these serotypes.

 

 

OPHTHALMIA NEONATORUM

 

  • Characterized by bilateral conjunctival inflammation in an infant (<30 day old).
  • Infact, any discharge/ watering from the eyes in the first week of life should arouse suspicion of ophthalmia neonatorum.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Serotypes A, B, Ba, C: These serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis are primarily associated with trachoma, a chronic keratoconjunctivitis that is a major cause of blindness in certain parts of the world. Trachoma is not typically seen in neonates.

 

Option C. Serotypes L1, L2, L3: These serotypes are responsible for lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), a sexually transmitted infection that affects the lymphatic system and is not typically associated with neonatal conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Serotypes 8 & 19: These serotypes are not standard classifications for Chlamydia trachomatis. They might be a mix-up with another classification system or an error.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, the responsible serotypes are D to K (option B). These serotypes are known for causing urogenital infections in adults and can lead to inclusion conjunctivitis in neonates when transmitted during childbirth.

 

Ref:

  1. Pg 67/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition;
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441840/

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient visited the ophthalmologist with complaints of Red, Watery Eyes with a slight gritty sensation since the past 10 days. After examination, he is diagnosed with Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis. Which Adenovirus Serotype is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 8 & 19.

 

Option D: 

 

Epidemic Kerato Conjunctivitis is caused by ADENOVIRUS serotypes- 8 & 19.

 

Other clinical features:

 

  • Associated with Keratitis and Preauricular Lymphadenopathy

  • Pseudomembrane lining the lower fornix.

  • Follicles in lower palpebral conjunctiva & fornix

  • SPKs-Superficial punctate keratitis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Serotypes 10 & 12: These serotypes are not typically associated with epidemic keratoconjunctivitis. Adenovirus serotypes 10 and 12 are more commonly associated with respiratory illnesses.

 

Option B. Serotypes 3 & 7: These serotypes can cause various adenoviral infections, including some forms of conjunctivitis, but they are not the most common causes of epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Serotypes 3 & 8: Serotype 3 is associated with a range of adenoviral infections, including conjunctivitis, but serotype 8 is one of the primary serotypes known to cause epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotypes 8 & 19 of adenovirus are most frequently responsible for cases of epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, which is characterized by symptoms like red, watery eyes and a gritty sensation.

 

Ref: Pg 74/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was brought to the ophthalmologist with complaints of red eyes with watery discharge. Mother also gave history of usage of an ophthalmic medication to prevent infection. After examination, a diagnosis of ophthalmia neonatorum is made. Which drug used must have caused this?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Silver Nitrate

 

Option A: Ophthalmia Neonatorum

 

  • Bilateral inflammation of the conjunctiva occurring in neonates (<30 days old).
  • Infact, any discharge/ watering from the eyes in the first week of life should arouse suspicion of ophthalmia neonatorum.
  • Credé’s procedure is the practice of washing a newborn's eyes with a 2% silver nitrate solution to protect against neonatal conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Azithromycin is an antibiotic and is not known to cause chemical conjunctivitis. Azithromycin eye drops or ointment may be used to treat bacterial causes of ophthalmia neonatorum, like Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Option C. Fluoroquinolones are broad-spectrum antibiotics and are generally not used as prophylaxis in newborns. They are not typically associated with causing chemical conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Tetracycline is another antibiotic option for the prevention of bacterial ophthalmia neonatorum, especially chlamydial infections. Like azithromycin, tetracycline is not known to cause chemical conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the history and clinical presentation, the most likely cause of the red eyes with watery discharge in this neonate is chemical conjunctivitis due to silver nitrate prophylaxis. This reaction is known as "silver nitrate conjunctivitis" and is characterized by a mild, self-limiting conjunctivitis with watery discharge, typically appearing within the first few days after administration.

 

Ref: Pg 77/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the clinical photograph below.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Symblepharon 

 

Option D: SYMBLEPHARON:

 

Adhesions between bulbar & palpebral conjunctiva

 

Causes:

 

  • Thermal and chemical burns
  • SJS, ocular pemphigoid etc

 

Rx:

 

  • Mobilising surrounding conjunctiva
  • Conjunctival/ buccal mucosal graft
  • Amniotic membrane graft

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ankyloblepharon: Adhesion between eyelids.

 

 

Option B. Trichiasis: Inward curling of eyelash.

 

 

Lower lid shows inward turning of eyelashes called trichiasis.

 

Option C. Chalazion: Meibomion cyst. Sterile chronic granulomatous inflammatory lesion (lipogranuloma) of the meibomian, or sometimes Zeis, glands caused by retained sebaceous secretions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symblepharon is an adhesion between the bulbar and the palpebral conjunctiva

 

Ref: Pg 376/ Eyelids/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: SAFE strategy is an effective intervention demonstrated in developing nations for the control of blindness caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Trachoma

 

Option C: SAFE strategy was an intervention done to combat trachoma.

 

  • Surgery to correct lid deformity & prevent blindness
  • Antibiotics for acute infections & community control
  • Facial hygiene
  • Environmental change- improved sanitation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cataracts are a leading cause of blindness globally and are characterized by the clouding of the lens in the eye. The primary intervention for cataracts is surgical removal of the cloudy lens and, if necessary, its replacement with an artificial lens.

 

Option B. Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, often due to abnormally high intraocular pressure. The treatment mainly involves eye drops, laser treatment, or surgery to lower intraocular pressure and prevent further damage to the optic nerve.

 

Option D. Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, onchocerciasis is caused by the parasite Onchocerca volvulus. It's transmitted to humans through the bites of infected blackflies. The strategy for controlling onchocerciasis primarily involves mass drug administration, particularly with the medication ivermectin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of global public health interventions, the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial cleanliness, Environmental improvement) is an effective approach specifically designed for the control and elimination of trachoma, a major cause of preventable blindness in developing nations.

questions.text: The lymphatics from the medial part of the conjunctiva drain into which group of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Submandibular

 

Option C:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pre-auricular Lymph Nodes are located just in front of the ears. They are responsible for draining lymph from the lateral part of the eyelids and conjunctiva, the frontal and temporal regions of the scalp, and the external auditory meatus.

 

Option B. Parotid Lymph Nodes, situated around the parotid gland, these nodes primarily drain the parotid gland itself, as well as parts of the face and scalp. They are not typically involved in the direct lymphatic drainage of the conjunctiva.

 

Option D. Submental Lymph Nodes, located under the chin, these nodes drain the central lower lip, floor of the mouth, tip of the tongue, and lower incisors. They are not directly involved in the drainage of the conjunctiva.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lymphatics from the medial part of the conjunctiva primarily drain into the submandibular lymph nodes. This is crucial to know as it can help in diagnosing and understanding the spread of infections or other pathologies related to the eye and its adjacent structures.

 

Ref: Pg 61/ Conjunctiva/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology/ AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angular conjunctivitis

 

Option C: 

 

Characterised by inflammation of conjunctiva & lid margins near the angles.

 

  • Causative organism: MORAXELLA AXENFELD

  • Also called: Diplobacillary conjunctivitis

  • Source of the infection is the nasal cavity, from where it reaches the eyes by contaminated fingers or handkerchief.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phlyctenular Conjunctivitis: This type of conjunctivitis is an immune response often associated with tuberculosis or staphylococcal infection. It is characterized by small, white, nodular lesions (phlyctenules) on the conjunctiva. While it causes discomfort and redness, it does not specifically manifest as angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Hyperacute Conjunctivitis is typically caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Neisseria meningitidis and is characterized by a very rapid onset and severe symptoms, including copious purulent discharge. It does not specifically present as angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Trachoma, chronic infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis leads to follicular conjunctivitis initially and, over time, can cause scarring. Trachoma typically involves the entire conjunctiva and not just the angular areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Angular conjunctivitis caused by Moraxella Axenfeld is characterised by inflammation of conjunctiva and lid margins near the angle.

 

Ref: Pg 66/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old female came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of irritation in the eyes, with whitish discharge collecting and redness at the angles of the eyes. She was diagnosed with Angular conjunctivitis. What is the most common causative organism of this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moraxella Axenfeld

 

Option B: Angular Conjunctivitis: Characterised by inflammation of conjunctiva & lid margins near the angles.

 

  • Causative organism: MORAXELLA AXENFELD
  • Also called: Diplobacillary Conjunctivitis

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chlamydia Trachomatis is known to cause trachoma and inclusion conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Neisseria Gonorrhoeae causes hyperacute purulent conjunctivitis, which is characterized by a rapid onset and severe, copious purulent discharge. It is not typically associated with angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus Aureus can cause various types of eye infections, including styes and blepharitis, and is a possible cause of conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Moraxella axenfeld Is the primary causative agent of angular conjunctivitis.

 

Ref: Pg 66/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: What is the incubation period for Gonococcal Ophthalmia Neonatorum?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 days

 

Option C:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 6 hours is too short for the incubation period of gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum. The infection usually takes longer to manifest symptoms.

 

Option B. 20 days is too long for the incubation period of gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum. The infection typically presents much sooner after birth.

 

Option D. 10 days is longer than the usual incubation period for gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms of gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum, such as redness, swelling, and purulent discharge from the eyes, generally appear within 2 to 5 days after birth in neonates exposed to Neisseria gonorrhoeae during delivery.

 

Ref: Pg 77/CONJUNCTIVA/Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/6th Edition

questions.text: A 6-day-old baby was brought to the OPD with complaints of Incessant Cry, Purulent Discharge from both eyes. The probable Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ophthalmia Neonatorum

 

  • Bilateral Inflammation the conjunctiva occurring in Neonate (<30 days old).
  • Infact, any discharge/ watering from the eyes in the first week of life should arouse suspicion of ophthalmia neonatorum.
  • Credé’s procedure is the practice of washing a newborn's eyes with a 2% silver nitratesolution to protect against neonatal conjunctivitis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epiphora refers to excessive tearing. It is common in infants due to congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. While it can cause tearing and some discomfort, epiphora typically does not lead to purulent discharge. It's more associated with watery discharge and might be accompanied by mucous but not the kind of purulent discharge described in the question. Congenital Nasolacrimal Duct Obstruction can be treated by Criggler’s massage, or may require Syringing and Probing and Dacryosurgery.

 

Option C. Ptosis is a drooping of the upper eyelid. It can be congenital or acquired and varies in severity. While ptosis can be present in infants, it would not typically present with purulent discharge or incessant crying unless associated with other eye conditions.

 

Option D. Congenital Cataract can lead to a decrease in vision but would not cause purulent discharge. The main signs would be a white reflex and possibly a lack of visual responsiveness or squint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the symptoms described – incessant crying and purulent discharge from both eyes in a 6-day-old baby – the most probable diagnosis is Ophthalmia Neonatorum. This condition necessitates prompt medical evaluation and treatment to prevent complications such as corneal damage and potential blindness.

 

Ref: Pg 77/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

choices.text: Povidone Iodine 2.5% Solution
1 % Tetracycline Eye Ointment
Ceftriaxone 75-100mg/kg/day IV 4 TID
All the above

questions.text: Treatment of Ophthalmia Neonatorum includes:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D:

 

Rx: X

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Povidone iodine 2.5% solution is an effective antiseptic and has been used in some settings for the prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum, particularly against bacterial and viral pathogens. However, it is not typically used as the primary treatment once an infection is established.

 

Option B. 1% tetracycline eye ointment is a traditional treatment for ophthalmia neonatorum, especially for cases caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Tetracycline eye ointment is effective against a broad range of pathogens.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone 75-100mg/kg/day IV 4 TID is an effective treatment for ophthalmia neonatorum caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Gonococcal conjunctivitis is a severe form of the disease and requires systemic antibiotic therapy, such as ceftriaxone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both tetracycline eye ointment and ceftriaxone are used in the treatment of ophthalmia neonatorum, the use of povidone iodine 2.5% solution is more preventive than curative in established cases.

 

REF: Pg77/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: A 22-year-old male, came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of pain, redness, watering in the eyes along with photophobia since 2 days. After examination, a diagnosis of haemorrhagic conjunctivitis is made. Which is the most common causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

 

Option D: Haemorrhagic Conjunctivitis is inflammation of conjunctiva characterised by multiple bulbar conjunctival haemorrhages.

 

  • Cause: Picornavirus (ENTEROVIRUS Type 70) and Coxsackie A24 variant.

  • Clinical features: Follicular hyperplasia, pre-auricular lymphadenopathy

  • Self-limiting course within 5-7 days

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While adenovirus is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis, it typically does not cause hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. The conjunctivitis caused by adenovirus is usually characterized by watery discharge, redness, and follicular conjunctival reaction.

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause such as retinitis in immunocompromised individuals, but it is not a typical cause of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) can lead to various ocular complications due to immune suppression. However, it is not directly associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common causative agent of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, which presents with symptoms like pain, redness, watering, and photophobia, is Enterovirus, particularly Enterovirus 70 and the Coxsackie A24 variant.

 

Ref:

  1. pg 77/ CONJUNCTIVA/ comprehensive ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th edition

  2. Wright PW, Strauss GH, Langford MP. Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Am Fam Physician. 1992 Jan;45(1):173-8. PMID: 1309404.

choices.text: Pseudomembrane Lining the Lower Fornix and Palpebral Conjunctiva
Pre Auricular Lymphadenopathy is present
Topical Steroids can be used during Active Inflammation
Superficial Punctate Keratitis is a typical feature of EKC.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about EKC?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical Steroids can be used during Active Inflammation

 

Option C:

 

EKC features:

 

  • Follicles and Pseudomembrane in the Lower Fornix.
  • Pre Auricular Lymphadenopathy is present.
  • Superficial Punctate Keratitis (SPKs) is a typical feature.

 

RX:

 

  1. Cold Compress
  2. Topical Antibiotics
  3. Topical Steroids are NOT used during Active Inflammation
  4. Weak Steroids- used if Subepithelial Infiltrates are present.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudomembrane lining the lower fornix and palpebral conjunctiva: In EKC, the formation of pseudomembranes is a common feature. These are fibrinous exudates that can be seen on the conjunctiva, particularly in severe cases. This statement is true.

 

 

Option B. Preauricular lymphadenopathy is present: EKC often leads to preauricular lymphadenopathy, which is swelling of the lymph nodes near the ear. This is a response to the viral infection and is a common clinical finding in EKC. This statement is true.

 

Option D. Superficial punctate keratitis is a typical feature of EKC: This is true. Superficial punctate keratitis, which is the presence of small, scattered lesions on the cornea, is a hallmark of EKC. It's a result of the inflammatory response to the viral infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis (EKC), the use of topical steroids during active inflammation is not universally recommended due to potential adverse effects and should be approached with caution.

 

Ref: Pg 74/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: Identify the probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haemorrhagic Conjunctivitis

 

Option D: Haemorrhagic Conjunctivitis- inflammation of conjunctiva characterised by multiple bulbar conjunctival haemorrhages.

 

  • Causative organism: Picornavirus (ENTEROVIRUS TYPE 70)
  • Clinical features: Follicular hyperplasia, pre auricular lymphadenopathy
  • Self-limiting course within 5-7 days

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bacterial Conjunctivitis typically presents with redness of the eye, tearing, and a purulent or mucopurulent discharge. While the conjunctiva can be inflamed, bacterial conjunctivitis does not usually cause a subconjunctival hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis caused by adenovirus, this condition presents with symptoms such as watery discharge, redness, swelling of the eyelids, and a feeling of irritation or foreign body sensation in the eye. It can be associated with subconjunctival hemorrhage, but other symptoms typically dominate the clinical picture, like corneal involvement (keratitis).

 

Option C. Herpetic Conjunctivitis is caused by herpes simplex virus and presents with eye redness, tearing, and may have characteristic dendritic ulcers on the cornea when examined under a slit lamp. Subconjunctival hemorrhage is not a typical feature of herpetic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given that the primary presentation in the question is subconjunctival hemorrhage, the most likely diagnosis is D. Haemorrhagic Conjunctivitis.

 

Ref: Pg 77/ CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

choices.text: Occurs due to sudden rupture of conjunctival capillaries
Blood dyscrasias like anemia, leukemia can cause SCH
Assurance is the most important part of treatment
None of the above

questions.text: Which among the following is not true about subconjunctival haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above

 

Option D: Subconjunctival haemorrhage:

 

Causes:

 

  1. Trauma
  2. Conjunctivitis
  3. Hypertension
  4. Bleeding disorders
  5. Post Ocular Surgery

 

Rx:  Absorbs within 7 to 21 days

Reassurance

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Occurs due to sudden rupture of conjunctival capillaries: This is true. Subconjunctival hemorrhage typically occurs due to the spontaneous rupture of small blood vessels in the conjunctiva. This can happen due to minor trauma, sudden increases in pressure (like coughing, sneezing, or straining), or even spontaneously without a clear cause.

 

Option B. Blood dyscrasias like anemia, leukemia can cause SCH: This is also true. Blood dyscrasias (disorders related to the blood) such as anemia or leukemia can predispose an individual to SCH. These conditions can affect the clotting mechanism or the integrity of blood vessels, making them more susceptible to bleeding.

 

Option C. Assurance is the most important part of treatment: This statement is generally true. In most cases, subconjunctival hemorrhage is a benign, self-limiting condition that does not require specific medical treatment. The primary approach is to reassure the patient about the nature of the condition, as it often resolves on its own without intervention. However, if an underlying systemic cause is suspected, such as hypertension or a blood dyscrasia, appropriate medical evaluation and treatment for these conditions are necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subcinjunctival Haemorrhage occurs due to sudden rupture of conjunctival capillaries, or blood dyscrasias. Assurance is an important part of treatment.

 

Ref: Pg 90/ / CONJUNCTIVA/ Comprehensive Ophthalmology AK KHURANA/ 6th Edition

questions.text: Safe strategy includes all, except which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enucleation

 

Option C: The SAFE strategy for trachoma management supported by the WHO.

 

Enucleation is the surgical removal of the eye and is not a part of the SAFE strategy for trachoma. It's a procedure typically reserved for severe, end-stage eye diseases where the eye is blind and potentially painful, but it is not a treatment for trachoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antibiotics: Trachoma is caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the use of antibiotics such as azithromycin or tetracycline eye ointment to treat active infection. This is a cornerstone of the SAFE strategy for trachoma control.

 

Option B. Facial Hygiene: Improved facial hygiene, especially regular face washing, can significantly reduce the transmission of trachoma. This is because the bacteria are spread through contact with discharge from the eyes and nose, particularly among children. Improved hygiene practices are an integral part of the SAFE strategy, aiming to reduce the incidence of new infections.

 

Option D. Surgical Correction: This refers to surgical procedures to treat trichiasis, a late complication of trachoma where eyelashes turn inward and scratch the cornea, potentially leading to blindness. The surgery corrects the position of the eyelashes and is an essential component of the SAFE strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of the SAFE strategy for trachoma control, the correct components are Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Surgical correction. Enucleation, which is the surgical removal of the eye, is not a part of this strategy and is reserved for other severe, end-stage ocular conditions.

 

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 176
